title: Kangra painting
summary: Kangra painting is a renowned pictorial art form originating from the Kangra State in Himachal Pradesh, India. It rose to prominence in the mid-18th century, eventually defining the broader Pahari painting school due to its significant volume and content. This exquisite art style was officially registered under the Geographical Indication of Goods Act on April 2, 2012. Historically patronized by Rajput rulers between the 17th and 19th centuries, its main centers included Guler, Basohli, and Kangra. Maharaja Sansar Chand was a pivotal patron, under whom it became the most important center of Pahari painting. Kangra art is now displayed in international museums, including those in Zurich, London, and Boston.
key_points: Kangra painting is a pictorial art from the Kangra State, Himachal Pradesh.
It became prevalent in the mid-18th century, succeeding the Basohli school of painting.
The style was registered under the Geographical Indication of Goods Act on April 2, 2012.
Major historical centers include Guler, Basohli, Chamba, Nurpur, Bilaspur, and Kangra.
Under Maharaja Sansar Chand, it became the most important center of Pahari painting.
Originated in Guler State in the first half of the 18th century by Kashmiri painters trained in the Mughal style.

17th-19th centuries: Kangra painting, as part of Pahari painting, was patronized by Rajput rulers.

current_status: Kangra painting is officially recognized and protected under the Geographical Indication (GI) Act. It remains a significant component of the broader Pahari painting school and its masterpieces are preserved and exhibited in prominent museums worldwide, including the Maharaja Sansar Chand Museum in Kangra, and international institutions in Zurich, London, and Boston.
future_prospects: Future prospects for Kangra painting involve continued efforts for its preservation, promotion, and protection as a GI-tagged art form. There is potential for further academic research and scholarly documentation, as well as the possibility of inspiring new generations of artists and cultural revival movements, ensuring its legacy endures.
